channel.title: Opinion-and-Essays on My News Feed
channel.description: Recent content in Opinion-and-Essays on My News Feed

item.title: Lakeland Echoes: Wind, Rock, Fell, Rain & Sea Power’s Krankenhaus
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> In the latest edition of our new column, Luke Turner reflects on the connection between Sea Power and the music of the landscape that surrounds their Krankenhaus festival. Photos by Paul Hudson of Down At The Front except Esk pics by Luke Turner.

item.title: What We Do With What We Have: Björk’s Medúlla Turns 20
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->Medúlla is arguably the point at which Björk turned from creating pop to a journey into the radically obscure, but in reality it is one of the most fully realised examples of an artist pushing the boundaries of what pop music can be and do, writes Matthew Barton

item.title: There Are No Horizons: Manic Street Preachers’ The Holy Bible Turns 30
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> Taylor Parkes picks through the bones of one of the best rock albums of the 1990s and the artistic apex of Manic Street Preachers’ history. This feature was first published on December 11, 2014

item.title: The Labels Shaping a New Ukrainian Underground Part 2: Money, Money, Money…
item.description: <!-- raw HTML omitted --><!-- raw HTML omitted --> In the latest edition of New Voices Ukraine, tQ’s new collaboration with 20ft Radio, Neformat, the British Council and Ukrainian Institute, Yaryna Denysyuk of Neformat, Yaryna Denysyuk continues her look into Ukrainian DIY record labels. Having surveyed those attempting utopian collective approaches in part one, this time she examines the unavoidable downsides of running a label during wartime
